reasoning: The critique targets an important inferential hinge: the essay’s frequent appeal to a ‘well‑informed’ default probability distribution over futures absent coordinated optimization, which is used to cash out “mostly-great futures are rare” and thus “narrow target.” If that default distribution can’t be grounded, the essay’s implied likelihood claims are underdetermined, so the attacked point is moderately central. However, the essay also offers largely distribution-independent reasons for fussiness/fragility (e.g., multiplicative-factor model, breadth of plausible moral views, bounded/unbounded value-function analysis), so undermining the default-distribution story doesn’t collapse the whole position. The critique’s force is limited because it mainly presses ‘no quantified/default model given’ rather than showing that plausible default dynamics would in fact make mostly-great futures common; it weakens evidential support more than it refutes. The critique is mostly correct and clearly stated, with little to no fluff, and it stays focused on one issue.
title: Ungrounded baseline distribution makes fragility claims underdetermined
